segments.text: Testing one two three four one two three four testing testing testing One two one two one two one two one two one two one two This is Friday August 18th
Had the pleasure and honor of chatting with Noel Parsons, who is soon to leave the Texas A&M Press to become director of the Texas Tech Press.
Noel, to introduce yourself to someone who might listen to this tape in the future or read the transcript, describe your background before you came to A&M.
Where did you grow up, what did mom and dad do, high school, college, experience before coming to A&M?
I grew up in East Central Oklahoma.
I was born in Holdenville and grew up there and in Ada and Wewoka.

graduated from high school and we woke up and So I was I was pretty much bound to to that part of Oklahoma and So when the time came for me to choose a college I Decided to go to the University of Oklahoma.
I really admired their football team so I went there to school and I
Graduated from there in 1964 and had a commission through ROTC in the Air Force.
Went into the Air Force for four years.
And then when I got out, I decided that I wanted to do something that would make some money.
My first major had been in Russian language, and so I didn't figure that was
something I could convert into dollars.
So I decided when I was going to go back to graduate school, I was going to major in something that I could use as a profession.
And so I selected journalism.
And I thought that after about a year of journalism school, I decided I didn't want to do newspaper work.
I wasn't cut out to be a reporter.
I could do it, but I didn't really enjoy it.
So I went to my graduate advisor and asked him what I could do with a journalism degree that didn't involve newspapers.
And he said, well, there's always magazines or books.
An aunt of mine had just written a book and had it published.
And I thought there was some mysterious process involved where you had to go to New York City and get involved in the publishing business there.
So I asked him, you know, how can I get involved in the book business?
It looked attractive.
It looked interesting.
And I'd always enjoyed reading books, and my aunt's experience had been a positive one.
So he told me that the University of Oklahoma Press had a fellowship program.
At the time, they were selecting two graduates a year.
to go through a year-long program of learning the publishing business there at the University Press.
And that sounded good, so I applied for that, and I got it.
And I've been in this business ever since.
Now, the director at that time was in?
The director was
Shaw, Ed Shaw.
And Savoy Lawtonville had just retired the year before.
Savoy Lawtonville was the real, he was the archetype of university press directors.
How's his last name spelled?
L-O-T-T-I-N-V-I-L-L-E.
I believe that's it.
But I got there a year too late to work under his supervision, although he was in and out a lot, and I did meet him.
But Ed Shaw was the director.
Mary Stith was the managing editor, one of the old-time by-the-book editors, just a wonderful person and wonderful editor.
So I was trained under her.
And did that for a year, and then I got a job with a publisher in Detroit that published books for the manufacturing industry.
Worked there for about two and a half years, then went to the University of Illinois Press for two and a half years, and then came here.
And that was what year?
It was 1975.
I started, we moved here August 18, 1975.
As a matter of fact, 25 years ago today.
Exactly.
What a coincidence.
I hadn't thought about that.
How did you and A&M become linked up?
Well, I had that job at Illinois, and the director there who had hired me, Dick Wentworth, had told me when I started there he couldn't pay me very much.
And so he was really encouraging me, but they didn't have a big budget for an assistant editor.
So he was encouraging me to look.
for jobs elsewhere, and I really did want to give back to the South or the Southwest if I could.

And so Diggs said one day, he said, let's go to the Association of American University Press' convention, which is being held in Indiana this year, and you can go with me and we'll camp in the state park there and go to the meetings.
And he said,
There's someone there I want you to meet.
This is a fellow.
He was the director of the University of Texas Press for a number of years.
And he's starting a new press in College Station at Texas A&M University.
And he'll be looking for a staff for that press.
And so he introduced me to Frank Wardlaw.
Well, Mary Stith was at that meeting, too.
And she had also advised Frank that he needed to talk to me, that I was a person that might fit into his plans for the staff here.
And so Frank and I got together and went to his room in the hotel where the convention was being held there.
And the first thing he did was ask me if I wanted a cigar.
And he pulled out a big old black cigar.
Fortunately, I was a smoker at the time, so that wasn't so bad.
Then he poured me a big stiff bourbon, and we sat in his room and talked about his ideas for what he wanted for the staff here and what I was planning to do.
So we came to an agreement, and he hired me.
Well, he actually, at that time, he invited me to come to College Station and take a look at the place.
And this would have been in early 75?
That was in June of 75.
This all happened pretty quickly.
As you recall that conversation with him, what did it seem that he was emphasizing about your task and about the press?
Well, Frank was... Frank was...
very task-oriented person.
Everybody on the team had a task, and all those tasks fit together to accomplish the publication, to accomplish the goal.
And so he wanted someone to be the in-house copy editor, and that's what he hired me to do.
And that's what I did.
And later he let me do a little
acquisition, but he was mainly the acquisitions editor.
Margaret Ingram was the managing editor, and she did some copy editing too, and then later on she did a little acquisitions too.
But until Lloyd Lyman came in as director, I really wasn't involved that deeply in acquiring books.
Did he, in that first conversation, did he give you any do's and don'ts?
any guidelines that he expected for you and for the press?
No, I don't think he did.
He just, he told me what he wanted to do here at Texas A&M, and he told me about all the support he had from the Aggies and the university.
But we really didn't go into specifics like that.
He had heard that I was a good copy editor.
I had Mary Stith's recommendation, which was really the best thing I could have had at the time, and Dick Wentworth's recommendation, too.
So I think he went on that, and we just talked generally about
the university and living in Texas and that kind of thing.
Did he give you any understanding of what topical areas, subject areas, he hoped to emphasize with the A&M Press?
Well, yeah, he did say that he did talk about the regional nature of the press, but he talked about
the fact that he hoped to do some things in publishing regional art that he hadn't been able to do at the University of Texas Press.
He alluded to some of the problems he'd had at Texas, but at that time I was young and naive and I really didn't pay that much attention to the political pressures that he'd been under.
Did he talk about number of books, titles a year he hoped to do?
Yes.
that the press was going to publish 18 to 20 books a year, and he hoped to keep it at that level.

He didn't want it to go much beyond that or much under that, because he wanted to publish really top-rate books, a few of them, so that the staff could really concentrate on doing a good job on all of them.
It's a good philosophy.
I wish we could have continued that.
Did he say anything about where the press reported and to whom he was responsible?
I don't recall at that time that we discussed that, that he talked about that.
I will tell you that after I came here and started work here, I was tremendously impressed because the first day I was here, practically,
the first or second day, he took me over to meet Jack Williams in Jack's offices.
And we sat down with the president of the university, president and chancellor of the university, and talked about publishing in the press.
And my hair was a little longer then than it is now.
And Jack commented on how maybe I'd want to,
get my hair cut so I'd fit into the looks of the community.
And then Jack also made some comments about, I told him I was from the University of Illinois Press, and he made some comments about marijuana smoking at some of the eastern universities.
But it was actually, it was a wonderful meeting and I really was
totally impressed with the fact that the president and chancellor would take the time to meet a junior editor.
Did you get the impression that he knew much about presses and was interested in the press?
Yes, oh yes, I did.
And he and Frank were perfectly, seemed to fit each other, complement each other perfectly in that way.
Frank had the technical expertise and Jack had the wherewithal to see that Frank's ideas and plans were carried out.
Did anybody, did any outsider as you, these people that had recommended you and so forth, did any of them give you any of their opinions about the press and about Wardlaw?
Oh, just about Wardlaw.
Of course, the press hadn't really been started yet.
Well, it had been going for about
nine months, eight months, something like that, but hadn't produced any books yet.
But Dick and Mary especially, Mary Stith, told me that Frank had been one of the top people in the Association of American University Presses.
I think he'd been president of the association a couple of times by that time.
And he had, of course, developed the University of Texas Press into one of the top presses in the United States by the mid-'70s.
And so his reputation was at the top.
I should tell you that at the same time, that same summer, at that same meeting, I got an offer from Ed Shaw.
to go back to the University of Oklahoma Press as managing editor, which would have been quite a promotion for me.
But I chose Texas A&M for two reasons.
Frank Wardlaw and the fact that Frank was able to go to the Association of Former Students and find some money to help me move.
I wouldn't have been able to afford the move back to Oklahoma.
But he found the funds to help us move from Champaign to College Station.
And that really was a major factor.
But also important was the opportunity to work with him and work under him and see how he ran a press.
I'm not going to ask any other dollar numbers.
What was your beginning salary?
Well, I don't remember.
My wife probably could tell you, but I think it was $12,000, but that may be high.
I may be thinking of a couple years down the road.
At Illinois, I was only making five or six.
And when I'd gotten out of the Air Force as a captain, I was making a lot more than that, and that had been seven years before.
As you got ready to move down here, what was your perception of Texas A&M before you arrived?
What did you think it was?
Well, going to the University of Oklahoma, I had some friends, had several friends from Houston.
I used to come down to Houston fairly often.
Of course, we'd always travel down I-45.
And as we passed this part of the country, my friends would always wave over to the right and say, over there is that Texas A&M where all those Aggies are.
And we would proceed on down the road to Houston, the center of the known universe at the time.
And so I really never had much of an opinion of Aggies.
I was told stories and jokes, of course.
But I never really knew anybody who'd gone to Texas A&M at that time.
When we came here and visited in July,
my wife's from Houston and and so we decided to drive down in July.

We stopped in Oklahoma and came on down through College Station on our way to visit her folks in Houston and stopped off with Frank and Rosemary and stayed in the apartments there in the old Board of Directors building through the press offices and they showed us around town and and
fed us and we were just really impressed with the place.
I remember we went over to the Grove and watched a movie and it was awfully hot.
The weather was really terrible that summer and we weren't used to it, having lived up north for five years.
So it was a memorable experience.
As you arrived,
and joined the community and the staff, how did you feel you were received by the community and by the press?
Oh, it couldn't have been any better.
And we felt that all the time we've lived here.
This is a wonderful community and a warm community.
I think they welcome newcomers with open arms.
no matter where the people come from.
I've always felt that.
What about as you were received by the press?
What about as you began work?
Oh, it was like finding a new family.
That's the way the press ran.
Frank was the patriarch, and the rest of us were family members.
Describe the make-believe I didn't know where the press was,
what its quarters were.
Describe the quarters for the press and then the staff.
The press was on the second floor of the old Board of Directors building, which was the old two-story frame house with the verandas around the front.
I don't know when it was built, 1912 maybe, 1910, 1912.
I've forgotten now.
But it was a beautiful, big, sprawling house.

and of course it had been divided up into a lot of rooms for suites really for the board members and they would stay there when they came for meetings and then after they had been given their new quarters over in the MSC why the the building was pretty much empty and when Frank had come to
to establish the press, that was the place that he wanted to put the press.
So Frank and Rosemary lived on the first floor, and then the second floor was the press offices.
And there was a stairway in the back up to the second floor.
That's how we got up to the offices.
The front of the building was the main office, Frank's office, with a big conference table in there.
And then Margaret's and Ray Grimala's offices were right outside of that, off the lobby.
Spell Grimala.
G-R-I-M-A-I-L-A.
Ray was the design manager, designer, production manager.
And he was from Wesleyan University Press.
He'd been there many years, and Frank hired him away from him.
He was an award-winning designer, and he was responsible for the look of the books and for the first 10 years or more of the press.
And then the business offices were there off the main lobby as well.
And then you went into a hallway, and there were some suites down the hallway, and I had one of those suites with my own bathroom.
And so I sat up there in the back of the building overlooking the Ward Law's backyard with the trumpet vine flowers growing over the trees and the bushes and shrubs, watching the birds fly.
And I could sit there and take a break from editing manuscripts.
And it was a wonderful place to work.
It was quiet and peaceful.
I really enjoyed it.
What were your personal goals as you began?
Well, my personal goals were to just to try to develop a career in publishing.
I was basically copy editing oriented at that time.
I wanted to do some acquisitions and
and grow in the business.
But I really wasn't given an opportunity to do that at that time.
But I was satisfied doing the job that I did, which was copy editing.
And in that role, you reported to who?
Margaret Ingram.
She was the first managing editor.
Describe Margaret and her style.
Oh, Margaret was wonderful.
She works for the state now.
In 1981, she left the press and went to law school and got a law degree and went to work for the state legislature drafting laws and checking laws for legal accuracy and so on.
And as far as I know, she's still doing that.
She works in the bowels of the state capitol over there in Austin.
But Margaret was wonderful and a good friend.
And she was from Kilgore, not Kilgore, Gilmer.
She was from Gilmer, Texas, East Texas, and she has a wonderful East Texas twang to her voice.
Who else was a copy editor other than you and her?
That's it.
We were the editorial office.
We were the editors.
All right, and so each of you were doing the, to start off, the eight to ten a year that Frank planned to...
I mean 18.
18 a year.
To 20?
We were doing all of the copy editing ourselves.
And do you remember what was your first, first, first?
My, oh gee.
Oh, I think my first one was in the Montag Oil
No, it was in the economic series.
It was by a fellow named Kopp, and it was on the NAFTA, not NAFTA, on OPEC and the oil crisis.
And I believe that was the first book I worked on here.
And I presume that oil was not your primary
area of emphasis as an undergraduate, that this might have been off your beaten track?
Oh, no, but a professional copy editor can edit anything.
Okay.
That's one of the things I liked about the job, is that there's such a variety of interesting material to work with, and you don't have to specialize in any of it.
I really, I am, I have a single track mind.
My mother's always told me that.
And I'm a jack of all trades.
And it's one of the reasons that I was pleased not to go on a complete graduate school, because I didn't want to get locked into any one thing.
Describe how a copy editor goes about editing a manuscript that's been submitted to a university press.
Well, it's not done the same way.
Describe then.
In-house, back then, we would take a manuscript and we'd sit down with it.
We'd start reading it.
We'd start correcting it and marking it up.

And after we'd done that, we'd send it to the author or sit down with the author, if possible, and go through it once again and go through every change that we'd made, especially the major changes, and discuss those with the author and work out any differences.
And the corrections and changes that we made were all to the Chicago Manual of Style.
And this was all done in blue pencil on paper.
And so then once we had reviewed the manuscript or the author had had a chance to review it, then we delivered it to production.
Of course, working with the illustrations and everything else involved was part of it, too.
Of course, nowadays, well, it's all done on computer.
And I've done some electronic copy editing, and I can do that, too.
But of course, like anything that computers are involved with, some of the glamour is gone, I think.
Some of the fun of it.
In the olden days, with the blue pencil,
Uh, normally you could do, uh, how many hundred pages a week?
Oh, man.
Or a manuscript.
It's been a long time since I've thought about those things.
Or a manuscript.
I, we could, well, if you figure you'd, we had to do, uh, ten manuscripts a year.
Okay.
So, uh, in about four or five weeks, we, it would take us four or five weeks working
pretty much straight through on it.
Of course, then once you had several manuscripts copyedited, they were in various stages of production, so then you had to handle proof on them, checking proof, and
and working behind the authors who were checking the proof, and then checking their indexes and so on.
So it wasn't all copy editing once you'd gotten started, gotten the books into the mill, into the pipe.
So I'd say it'd take three to four weeks to edit an average-sized monograph.
It really varied a lot depending on the density of the writing and the problems involved with it.
There must have been a comparatively early manuscript you dealt with that you look back upon as a real important early step.
If so, what was it?
Well, let me tell you, I was the copy editor for Frank Gould on his book, Common Texas Grasses.
Now, the press, when I got to the press, they had already contracted to publish and were in the process of publishing his big book, Grasses of Texas.
That had been started by the agriculture school.
And then when Frank came, he more or less acquired that from the ag school and said, well, why not let the press publish it and publish it as a university press book?
But Common Texas Grasses was a condensation of that book, and that was one that was assigned to me for copyediting.
So I worked with Frank Gould, and I went through his manuscript
and copy edited it pretty thoroughly and thought I'd done a pretty good job on it.
I was really pleased and I always enjoyed working with natural history books and the methodical nature of the material that's presented, consistency from one account to another.
And so I had done a good job on that one until I sat down with Frank and he informed me that Webster's
The standard dictionary was not the standard for botanists to use in the spelling of grass names.
He told me that it was done a certain way and we had to have it done for that book.
Well, being a copy editor, I was insistent that we stick with Webster's in the spelling of those names.
He was just as insistent that he was right.
So I took the problem to Frank and explained to Frank that we had this disagreement, and Frank, in his very diplomatic way, suggested that I...
